author: sina.com.cn
title: 泉州青工以弱胜强晋级|中乙_新浪财经_新浪网
text:
本报讯 （记者 肖榕） 近日，2025赛季中国足协杯结束了首轮全部比赛。福建共有3支球队出赛，最终泉州青工走走纺织队顺利晋级下一轮。值得一提的是，福建球队这3场比赛共吸引超过2200名球迷入场观赛，占首轮16场比赛观赛总人数的17%。
泉州青工走走纺织队是一支业余球队，今年将参加中冠联赛。面对职业队、来自中乙的杭州临平吴越队，泉州青工以弱胜强，通过点球大战险胜对手。
下一轮，该队将挑战中甲球队苏州东吴队。“作为一支草根球队，我们能在主场迎来中甲球队，这将是一次非常难得的机会。不论比赛结果如何，我们会让球员好好享受比赛。”球队总经理洪琦琳说。
另外两支福建球队则被挡在了首轮门外，其中包括唯一一支职业队、来自中乙的泉州亚新队。主场面对温州足球俱乐部队，泉州亚新队在先丢一球的情况下连扳两球，但到了下半场又再丢两球，最终2∶3不敌对手。
泉州亚新队主教练杨小奇介绍，今年球队以U21球员为主，且都是本省培养的球员，“希望借助足协杯和中乙联赛的平台，给年轻球员锻炼机会，做好年轻球员的培养工作”。
在厦门海沧体育中心，同为业余球队的厦门集美诚毅队以0∶3不敌来访的中乙球队江西庐山，也止步首轮。
足协杯第二轮比赛将于4月中旬举行。

title: 3 Days After Rajouri Terror Ambush, J&K Ex-Policeman Shot Dead Inside Mosque; 2nd Cop Attack In Dec | Hindustan Times
text: Explore Search Sunday, Dec 24, 2023 New Delhi o C Games E-Paper Sign in My Account Start 14 Days Free Trial Subscribe Enjoy unlimited access Subscribe Now! Get features like Ad lite A Minimal Ad Experience HT Premium Articles Expertly crafted articles Quickreads Segment News brief in summary format HT E-paper Access digital news experience Start 14 Days Free Trial Home Latest News Cricket Education India World Cities Entertainment Lifestyle Astrology Editorials Shop Now 2024 Planner Live Score HT Premium HTCity videos Photos Trending Web Stories Tech Business Sports Delhi News Mumbai News Bengaluru News Quickreads Daily Digest Following IPL Games + 7 more Mumbai News Bengaluru News Quickreads Daily Digest Following IPL Games News / Videos / News / 3 Days After Rajouri Terror Ambush, J&K Ex-Policeman Shot Dead Inside Mosque; 2nd Cop Attack In Dec 3 Days After Rajouri Terror Ambush, J&K Ex-Policeman Shot Dead Inside Mosque; 2nd Cop Attack In Dec news Published on Dec 24, 2023 01:15 PM IST Follow Us Follow Us Share Via Copy Link A retired J&K Superintendent of Police, Mohammed Shafi, was shot dead by terrorists in Baramulla district on December 24. The incident took place when a former J&K police officer was praying azan at a mosque in the Gantmulla area. J&K police, in a post, said the Shafi succumbed to injuries. The area has been cordoned off to nab the terrorists. The attack came two days after three J&K civilians who were taken for questioning following the December 21 terror attack on the Army were found dead. author: @Live_Hindustan
title: दिल्ली में प्रदूषण का जहर घोल रहे आधा फीसदी वाहनों पर भी नहीं हुई कार्रवाई, देखिए डेटा
text:
Hindi News
एनसीआर Newsno action on even half of delhi old vehicles creating air pollution see full stats
दिल्ली में प्रदूषण का जहर घोल रहे आधा फीसदी वाहनों पर भी नहीं हुई कार्रवाई, देखिए डेटा
यह जानकारी केन्द्रीय वायु गुणवत्ता प्रबंधन आयोग की रिपोर्ट में सामने आई। अलग-अलग शोध बताते हैं कि वाहनों से निकलने वाले धुएं की दिल्ली के प्रदूषण में हिस्सेदारी 42 फीसदी या उससे ज्यादा हो सकती है।
दिल्ली-एनसीआर की हवा में प्रदूषण का जहर घोलने वाले पुराने वाहनों पर कार्रवाई बेहद सुस्त है। बीते दो वर्ष में अपनी समय अवधि पूरी कर चुके सिर्फ एक फीसदी वाहनों पर ही दिल्ली में कार्रवाई हुई,जबकि एनसीआर के जिले और भी पिछड़े हुए हैं। वहां पर आधा फीसदी भी पुराने वाहनों पर कार्रवाई नहीं हो पाई है।
यह जानकारी केन्द्रीय वायु गुणवत्ता प्रबंधन आयोग की रिपोर्ट में सामने आई। अलग-अलग शोध बताते हैं कि वाहनों से निकलने वाले धुएं की दिल्ली के प्रदूषण में हिस्सेदारी 42 फीसदी या उससे ज्यादा हो सकती है। विशेषज्ञों के मुताबिक,आम वाहनों की तुलना में समय अवधि पूरा कर चुके वाहनों से ज्यादा प्रदूषण होता है। इसलिए पुराने वाहनों के संचालन पर रोकथाम की जाती है।
आंकड़ों के मुताबिक, वर्ष 2023 और 2024 में दिल्ली में सिर्फ एक फीसदी पुराने वाहनों पर ही कार्रवाई की जा सकी। जबकि, हरियाणा के एनसीआर जिलों में केवल 0.15 फीसदी पुराने वाहनों पर ही कार्रवाई की गई। उत्तर प्रदेश में 0.4 फीसदी और राजस्थान के एनसीआर जिलों में 0.24 फीसदी वाहनों पर ही कार्रवाई हुई है। कार्रवाई में सुस्ती का अंदाजा इससे भी लगाया जा सकता है कि 2023 में हरियाणा के एनसीआर जिलों में 220 वाहनों पर कार्रवाई हुई।
Hindi News,
बॉलीवुड न्यूज,
बिजनेस न्यूज,
क्रिकेट न्यूज,
धर्म ज्योतिष,
एजुकेशन न्यूज़,

author: CBS News
title: California man missing for more than a week found alive
text:
A California man was found alive more than a week after he went missing.
Lukas McClish, 34, was reported missing by his family on June 11, officials said on social media . He was last seen on foot in the Boulder Creek area of Santa Cruz, wearing all-black clothing.
At around 3 p.m. local time on Thursday, several witnesses reported “hearing someone yelling for help” near Foreman Creek, off an area highway, the Santa Cruz County Sheriff’s Office said on social media . Deputies and other officials responded to the scene and confirmed that it was McClish calling for help.
Drones were used to find McClish’s exact location in a remote canyon before officials attempted to reach him on foot. State parks rangers met McClish first. Fire crews were then able to assist in bringing him to safety. Photos show officials gathered around a densely wooded area.
Luke has been found! He’s safe and back with loving friends and family. Thank you to our amazing community who rallied…
Posted by Boulder Creek Volunteer Fire Department on Friday, June 21, 2024
“There are no trails, no roads, several miles from the closest place to a road, which the closest road that we got into, we had to four-wheel drive probably a quarter of a mile in and then we couldn’t go further,” Boulder Creek Fire Protection District Chief Mark Bingham told local news outlet The Santa Cruz Sentinel .
McClish needed assistance to hike out of the woods, Bingham said, but he had no major injuries and has been reunited with his family, the sheriff’s office said. The Boulder Creek Volunteer Fire Department said on social media that McClish had survived out in the elements for more than a week.
“About 10 days he survived in the wilderness, essentially, drinking out of the creek and eating wild berries,” Bingham told the Santa Cruz Sentinel. “For the most part, he was disoriented and lost and surviving off of the land, which is pretty impressive to say what a tough individual he was or is.”
Kerry Breen
Kerry Breen is a news editor at CBSNews.com. A graduate of New York University’s Arthur L. Carter School of Journalism, she previously worked at NBC News’ TODAY Digital. She covers current events, breaking news and issues including substance use.
The post California man missing for more than a week found alive appeared first on CBS News .

Una anécdota: Sederot es una localidad "israelí" (robada a los palestinos, claro) que se encuentra muy cerca de Gaza. Muchos de los cohetes que Hamas tiraba a israel impactaban allí, por cercanía (ya que estos no tienen mucho alcance). Los daños eran mínimos: algún que otro edificio chamuscado y poco más. Pero lo vendían como pobres víctimas y les llovía la pasta de los sionistas de EE.UU. Cuando Israel creo el escudo protector, ellos se quejaron porque decían que ya no les enviaban tanta pasta...
[#126](c126#c-126) Yo creo que la humanidad como especie sobreviviría, estamos muy extendidos. Una guerra nuclear global acabaría con los estados que conocemos y con la civilización en su conjunto, morirían miles de millones de personas y quedaría gran parte de las zonas habitadas por humanos destruidas e inhabitables.
Pongamos que las bombas se tiran donde hay población humana y no donde no la hay, quedarían amplias regiones del planeta sin destruir y pequeños grupos de humanos esparcidos por puntos remotos.
[#5](c5#c-5) Y entre nazis. Mira mi pequeña santamontes... hay suerte de que los listos sean los buenos porque si fuéramos nazis no querríamos a los tontos que nos acechan en esta pródiga vida. No hablaríamos de razas sino de acabar con los miserables que no quieren oir el porvenir de la razón. Pero no somos nazis como los tontos, aunque sabemos lo que harían con nosotros. Guárdate esta lección para tus hijos porque tal vez tras el invierno nuclear las cosas ya no sean así.

Lo raro es afirmar las cosas que afirmas y no aportar ni una sola prueba que fundamente tu comentario. Es que, yo no se ni si estás contestando a la persona adecuada, porque el 85% del comentario son datos de los países que se unieron a la OTAN y en que año.
Y el resto del comentario las veces que la OTAN he intervenido en misiones de paz bombardeando países mostrando mi desacuerdo en sus intervenciones. ¿Pero narrativa? Me da que has venido a desacreditar al mensajero porque los datos no te gustan y claro unos datos que contradicen tu versión sesgada sólo te deja dos opciones. Reconocer que estás desinformado o atacar al que da los datos. Si quieres te pongo la Wikipedia en Inglés para ver si contradice los datos que he enumerado.
Estoy deseando ver tu contestación, a ver sí corriges los datos que he puesto o si vas a seguir faltando el respeto, insultando y desviando la conversación a vías que no conducen a nada mas que a obviar los hechos. Hechos que están documentados y firmados.

author: Dennis Bova
title: Nursing student helps design life-saving project for elderly
text: A senior citizen is passed out on the floor of his Wilmington residence. First responders arrive but do not know the person’s medical history. But on the refrigerator door is a completed medical form in a sealed plastic bag telling the responders what they need to know. It’s a result of a program based on the American Red Cross’s Vial of Life, adapted for elderly residents in Wilmington by a group of Wright State University nursing students, including a student whose own health problems inspired her to care for others. Last fall, nursing students in public health classes were assigned to study nearby small communities. A group of nine students studied Wilmington by vehicle, foot, via research and through interviews with a cross-section of residents. One of those students was Reed Pitstick, a senior nursing major who lived near Wilmington as a child. “I always went to Wilmington with my parents,” she recalled. “It’s a full-circle moment. Being able to make an impact close to where I grew up makes me hopeful that that community will improve from what we did.” The students determined Wilmington’s elderly population could be vulnerable because most do not have vital health information ready for first responders. The goal became to have that information easily at hand. Pitstick said Wilmington’s public safety officials were approached about reviving the Vial of Life program, which had been in the city years ago but has since lapsed. In this program, a resident’s health information is usually listed on paper rolled into a tube kept in a refrigerator. The nursing students struggled to find funds for or suppliers of cylinders. So, each student donated sealable, clear-plastic sandwich-sized bags. “We took the Vial of Life idea and updated it,” said Pitstick, who now lives in South Charleston. One major addition was to include a code status for whether the resident has a do-not-resuscitate order or whether first responders were to do whatever is necessary to get a heartbeat. The bags included instructions explaining code statuses and a form listing the resident’s emergency contacts, medications, medical history, past diagnoses, names of their health care providers, whether the resident has a pacemaker and other pertinent information. The students distributed 400 bags through Wilmington city authorities. The bags included two Vial of Life stickers, which Pitstick designed — one for the front door to alert first responders and the other attaching the bag to the refrigerator door. Though the students wrapped up their project in December, it lives on through materials from live presentations they gave now available at the Wilmington library. Included is a QR code that leads to the instructions and forms that can be printed and distributed. The project is important to Pitstick. “We’ve planted a seed that can grow if people in the community find it helpful,” she said. “We focused on the elderly, but it can be made impactful for other populations, like the homeless, the less fortunate or those who didn’t have access to our project.” Her sympathy and empathy for others — and her drive to be a nurse — grew from personal experience. “I never knew I wanted to be a nurse until high school when I ran into a health problem,” Pitstick said. A student-athlete, she developed an irregularly fast and erratic heartbeat, a condition called supraventricular tachycardia. “In October of my junior year of high school I had two emergency heart surgeries, one day after the other,” she recalled. Thirteen months later, she had a third heart surgery. All were in Nationwide Children’s Hospital in Columbus. “I had a great experience,” she said. “I loved talking to the nurses to see what they do. It was during that last hospital stay that the notion entered my mind to go to nursing school.” She toured Wright State and after high school graduation, she enrolled. “Wright State has a highly rated nursing program,” she said. Pitstick’s heart now is fine, and she has resumed being an athlete, playing co-ed recreational volleyball and sand volleyball. Pitstick is now doing a capstone project on post-partum care. “That’s where I want to work as a nurse, with new mothers and their babies,” she said. “I want to have an impact on that patient population.” Wright State’s nursing program has helped Pitstick develop confidence in her nursing skills. “There are a lot of skills labs and simulations, a lot of hands-on learning,” she said. “There are a lot of great clinical instructors who are motivating.” [1 Kettering Army dad surprises kids at school, returning after seven...](/local/kettering-army-dad-surprises-kids-at-school-returning-after-seven-months-away/UOFDLMC3BZFHJEKRZRGEAAC4PE/) [2 $150K in equipment reportedly stolen in break-in at Greene County...](/local/deputies-investigating-after-thefts-reported-at-greene-county-airport/32ASVQ2RGVE7TCOP2KXNZ42BJQ/) [3 VA halts taking away gun rights from veterans who require help managing...](/local/va-halts-taking-away-gun-rights-from-veterans-who-require-help-managing-their-benefits-but-only-for-6-months/67VADXSQBFCRHAQCPNHMPXCIEA/) [4VA ordered to end experiments on dogs, cats and primates by 2026](/local/va-ordered-to-end-experiments-on-dogs-cats-and-primates-by-2026/IM44FTM6K5HITBSXKECZV7H7OI/) [5 Five Rivers MetroParks explores new tax levy, citing $58M backlog of...](/local/five-rivers-metroparks-explores-new-tax-levy-citing-58m-backlog-of-projects/UMD7FP6K7NCWBL2AVTBMI2M2VQ/) About the Author

author: Dan Belson
title: Federal judge overturns jury’s guilty verdict in Gambrills doctor’s health care fraud case
text:
A federal judge acquitted a Gambrills physician last week in a rare ruling that cast aside a jury’s August verdict that found the doctor guilty of multiple health care fraud counts.
U.S. District Judge James K. Bredar, who presided over the three-week trial this summer, wrote in his decision that he found the case’s record “lacks evidence from which a reasonable jury could find that” certain statements made by Dr. Ron Elfenbein, the former director of an urgent care chain headquartered in Gambrills, were false.
The judge noted in his Dec. 21 memorandum that he “does not take lightly” his decision to throw aside the jury’s guilty verdict on the Medicare billing fraud counts for submitting more than $15 million in claims, which the government alleged were fraudulent, for patients who received COVID-19 tests.
“This is the rare case that merits overturning the jury’s verdict,” he wrote, adding that having observed the trial and having “carefully parsed” the case’s record, he concluded “that
the jury’s verdict cannot stand.”
A spokesperson for the Maryland U.S. Attorney’s office said prosecutors had no comment on Bredar’s decision, which also conditionally granted defense attorneys’ request to give Elfenbein a new trial in the event the Department of Justice wins an appeal of the decision. Prosecutors had not filed any notice that they intended to appeal the case as of Thursday afternoon.
Elfenbein, a doctor from Arnold who opened the Gambrills-based chain of First Call Medical Center locations after multiple runs for office, now “looks forward to getting his life back together,” former Baltimore State’s Attorney Gregg Bernstein, part of the physician’s defense team, said Thursday.
He said Elfenbein and his legal team were “of course thrilled by Judge Bredar’s very thoughtful, detailed and comprehensive decision,” which he said agreed with “what we believed all along, which was that Dr. Elfenbein is innocent.”
The former emergency care physician resigned from his position as medical director of the urgent care chain after being indicted in April 2022 on charges stemming from his company’s billing claims. Federal prosecutors alleged the urgent care facility billed insurers for complex medical procedures when the establishment had simply given patients COVID-19 tests. The doctor’s indictment turned attention to then-Del. Sid Saab, who was
connected to the urgent care business but resisted questions about the scope of his involvement. The Republican candidate sued his opponent in that year’s general election for defamation, in part referencing campaign mailers — which were not actually sent by Sen. Dawn Gile — connecting Saab to Elfenbein’s indictment. He dropped the suit after losing to Gile, a Severna Park Democrat.
Federal prosecutors later expanded the charges to include allegations the urgent care chain fraudulently billed other insurers, like Medicaid, CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield and the Health Resources and Services Administration COVID-19 Uninsured Program.
Awaiting sentencing after the jury’s Aug. 4 verdict, Elfenbein faced a maximum penalty of 10 years in federal prison for each of the five counts. The sentencing hearing, originally scheduled for November, was put off as Bredar considered defense attorneys’ motion to acquit the physician.
Much of the government’s case hinged on the urgent care chain’s use of certain medical billing codes, which prosecutors alleged overcharged the insurers. Elfenbein’s defense team argued during the trial, and in their argument to acquit the doctor, that there was enough ambiguity in the definitions of the billing codes that prosecutors could not establish that the urgent care falsely submitted claims under the wrong key. In his decision last week, Bredar sided with the defense team, finding “the evidence does not support the jury’s apparent finding that billing” at a different level for the COVID-19 tests “was false or fraudulent.”

author: world today news
title: NFL Preseason: Thunderstorm ends Houston vs Chicago
text:
Written in SPORTS he 1/8/2024 · 21:38 hs
Canton, Ohio.- The preseason of the NFL with the classic meeting of Hall of Fame which on this occasion would be contested by Houston Texans y Chicago Bears However, the news is that the game could not be concluded, due to bad weather in Ohio .
There were 3:31 left to play in the third quarter and Chicago had the ball after the failed field goal attempt Kaimi Fairbarn from 58 yards, when the referees decided to suspend the game momentarily due to the thunderstorm, however, after half an hour of waiting and seeing that the rain did not stop, the NFL decided to suspend the match, and end it with the score 17-21 in favor of Bears .
On the sporting level, the highlight was Brett Wrinkling the quarterback of Chicago who scored in three of the four offensive series in which he participated. Wrinkling He met twice Collin Johnson while the third pass to the diagonals was in connection with Tommy Sweeney .
In addition, by land, Bears He added 86 yards on 15 carries, highlighting Khalil Herbert with 45 yards on four attempts, the most productive being a 19-yard scamper.
By Texans , Davis Mills He threw for 102 yards, connecting on 10 of 13 attempts and getting a touchdown pass. Also notable were Teagan Quitoriano y Cam Aikers both with two receptions and a touchdown.
What’s next in the NFL preseason? From the Thursday, August 8th the teams of the NFL will have their preseason games, starting with Carolina Panthers vs New England Patriots y Detroit Lions vs New York Giants ; for him Friday 9th we will have Atlanta Falcons vs Miami Dolphins , Houston Texans vs Pittsburgh Steelers y Philadelphia Eagles vs Baltimore Ravens .
